author: Patzn98
title: Endoscopy
body:
I was booked at Mt Stuart hospital Torbay for an endoscopy today. The staff were wonderful, caring and helpful. We agreed that I would have sedation. Some where between that discussion & getting to the procedure room, my doctor had changed their mind and went ahead with the procedure without sedating me.  
It was an extremely traumatic experience. My oesophagus is raw and swollen (which is why I was having the procedure) and they pushed the tube down my throat and twisted and manoeuvred it around. & into my stomach. I was gagging and was in such pain and shock that I find it hard to put into words. It took several painful and traumatic minutes, my eyes were watering, my mouth was running with saliva from the constant gag reflex...it truly was awful.  
What allowed me to get through it was the wonderful nursing staff, who held my hand and tried to keep me calm throughout this ordeal.  
In my opinion this is not a procedure anyone should go through without some form of sedation. My doctor was a lovely person who spent time discussing my health and reassuring me and the nursing staff were tremendous but I’m baffled as to why I was put through it without our agreed sedation. To be honest it will take me some time to recover from this experience.

author: John23
title: Patient pass away
body:
Devastated from start to finish. No information from the hospital, they told us the consultant was going to call but no call at all. I called them back and get the response of what do you want? So rude, if that is how they are treating relatives, how are they treating patients?  
Family member passed away this morning so we get told that the doctor will call us with all the details. We are now 10pm and no call to explain. They never once tested for COVID as we kept asking "so has he got COVID?" and they kept responding not tested yet. Now, we thought everyone gets COVID tested, but apparently not as he wasn’t. The way this hospital are treating us is a joke.

readBy.name: Barking, Havering and Redbridge University Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Justamum13
title: Melatonin
body:
My son has been taking melatonin since he was 6. He is now almost 11. He was prescribed 4mg at night. Now as he has gotten older the melatonin is not having the same affect and he really struggles to sleep at night.  
When I contacted the gp about reviewing his medication I was told he would need to see the paediatrician. A referral was put to the paediatrician (for behavioural difficulties as well as for the melatonin)who then refused the referral as he has asd so signposted to enable and one stop shop.  
When I then asked the gp what to do about the need for the review of the melatonin he couldn’t answer me apart from to say it needed a specialist to review. So how on earth do we go about seeing someone when referrals are declined? We are just going round in circles and my son is seriously struggling to sleep at night even though he is absolutely exhausted

author: shuddergb98
title: Covid vaccination - too many people for the space
body:
Very pleased to have vaccination letter, quick appointment and excellent staff. Very streamlined and efficient but very friendly. HOWEVER  
premises were very worrying and totally unlike centres seen on TV - very low ceilinged portacabin, small room with no sign of ventilation; individual tables just about 2 metres apart but no screens; hygiene excellent BUT too many tables, too many people for the space (30ish patients and staff). Despite the staffs best and diligent efforts it felt very unsafe. I am counting down to 14 days in case the crowding might cause an outbreak of the very virus it is aiming to control!

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Lindo
title: A&E care at Dr Gray’s
body:
While in recent years I have personally had good care at A&E at Dr Gray’s, it is unfortunate that this has not been the case since early 2020.  
The misdiagnosis and initial neglect of a torn meniscus in January 2020 by a GP at A&E has now led to the extended damage to my spine, as bending properly has not been possible. The delay of any medication or treatment for osteoporosis since 2018 has culminated in poor care for a rupture in my spinal lumbar this week by a Locum, when I have been given medication content with an intolerance ingredient which has serious side effects, this despite being told of the allergy. I am left wondering when proper safe professional care can be offered.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Jaycw57
title: My mum is now housebound
body: My mum was taken in to fazakerly hospital at the beginning of December with a broken shoulder. She was put in the frailty ward for 2 days until her covid test came through negative. She was then put on to ward 21. Because of covid there was no visiting so we thought we would get updates from the ward, we rang from the saturday until the Tuesday and ended up having to travel to the hospital to get some answers. They asked if my mum had dementia! No, she didn’t have dementia, was she incontinent, no, the long and short of it is she spent 3 weeks in there because of their treatment of here and 2 stone lighter, when I asked her how come she has lost all that weight she said because of her shoulder she could only use one hand to eat and the plate kept moving, when she asked for help they said they were too busy! My mum was a healthy 90 year old who did her own shopping, went to bingo, went to the hairdressers in her own. She is now housebound and has lost all of her confidence. Shame on the staff who are supposed to be caring.

readBy.name: Liverpool University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

title: Waiting times to see a GP is too long
body: Every time I go to this practice I am waiting 45-60 minutes to see a doctor despite having an appointment

author: NLe2021
title: Care received
body: I was admitted to a& e after attempting to take my only life. Now I’ll be honest I don’t remember my whole experience but I do remember the kindness and compassion I received from every nurse I met in ICU. I will be forever grateful to them for everything they did for me. Thank you

author: sierratx96
title: Support from PSL
body:
When I discovered my son was addicted to drugs it was a bewildering and worrying time. I felt as if it must have been something I had done wrong as I was a mum and didn't feel I could share it with anyone as I would be judged. For a long time I just hoped he would find a way and "grow out of it" as he wasn't open to discussion or help and got progressively more aggressive at home. This caused my younger child to be fearful of what may happen next and I explained that if he didn't live by the simple house rules of keeping us all safe from his chosen habits then he would need to leave. He chose to leave and continued to use drugs and alcohol to mask his feelings and deal with his deteriorating mental health.  
It was heart breaking to see my beautiful boy ravaged by harder drugs and a regular habit became a daily need and addiction had taken control of him. It led to attempts at suicide, which thankfully weren't successful and periods of homelessness. This further entrenched his feeling of worthlessness and it was a vicious cycle of using drugs to mask his deep depression. When he one day reached out and told me the truth of his addiction, he was brave enough to search out help with Inclusion and I heard about PSL and the support groups they offered to family and friends of anyone addicted to any substance.  
At last I had somewhere safe I could speak openly about the type of drugs he was on, share the feelings of shame, guilt and powerlessness to "make it better for him"  
The group and the amazing therapists at PSL have, through 1 to 1 counselling, wellness sessions and group discussion helped me through the hardest times without judgement and at any time of the day or night.  
Today 9 years on and my son still has an addiction but he has a home, engages with Inclusion and is much more able to talk about his feelings. I still value the support PSL give me as I don't know how I would continue to help him stay on the "straight and narrow" and constantly be his support in budgeting, keeping healthy, eating well and offering a stable family to call when he needs to talk or visit to remind him he is loved and valued. We still have blips and the responsibility feels overbearing sometimes but PSL have helped me learn to cope in difficult situations and be able to step away and keep myself safe when I need to.  
Without PSL I may have given up on him for the sake of my own sanity but with support you can find the strength to encourage your loved one without compromising your own safety and wellbeing. Thank you to all the team

author: AlM2021
title: Care following stroke
body: I was admitted to orthopaedics to have a surgery. While I was being prepared for surgery I doctors noticed I I had lost movement in my left side. and my speech was very poor. I believe I was then rushed to the CT scanner where they found a clot on my brain. I was rushed to theatre where a procedure called a thrombectomy was performed. The nursing staff in the stroke unit have told me, this is a new procedure and I am one of the first in Tayside to receive this treatment. I was in theatre for 2 hours where the clot was completely removed and I am back to my normal self. I am now fit enough to undergo my surgery now. This is due completely to the wonderful care I have received consistently from the amazing drs and nurses especially the stroke team. So therefore I thank everyone for saving my life.

author: poppies59
title: Services not keeping promises
body: I'm supporting a relative who has health conditions and she also has 3 autistic children. We have tried to apply for SDS and a Carers Assessment. Everyone promises us to take action then there is absolutely no contact whatsoever. I am deeply disappointed.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: mmullins
title: Live kidney donor full assessment day
body:
I was treated with first class treatment, the kidney co-ordinator's were fantastic girls! I am so happy with my experience, so efficiently run and friendly and everyone in every department were communicating with each other for a smooth day of scanning and bloods etc.  
I am so happy with this service and am looking forward to the future dealing with City Hospital Belfast.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: antliaqg86
title: Terrible care of my granddaughter.
body:
My 13 year old granddaughter hurt her leg in December. She attended RAH early hours the next day. She had 2 x-rays but staff unable to say broken or not. They tried to get her to walk but she could not weight bear, nurse tried to bandage her knee when it was her ankle which had suspected break.  
Her mum was told consultant would look at it and call and she was sent home with a boot on. Someone called the following day and said it looked broken and she would need a scan. The hospital were contacted daily to ask when and her mum was told could not say as all scanners were being used for covid patients. Then told consultant would speak to her on his ward round, they were told she was not on a ward but was at home.  
Eventually got call from RHC Glasgow to attend for scan a week later same day got call from RAH to come for scan but took the RHC appointment. Was scanned and her ankle is broken with a piece of bone broken off also. Was told report had to go to RAH. Called RAH to ask what was happening and told it was being referred back to RHC.  
Later on was called by RAH to say sorry for all this bother and that as she had now left the ward they would close case. Her mum had to tell them once again she had never been in a ward and found what they were saying strange as RAH does not have a children's ward anymore. It is now 10 days that my granddaughter has been left in pain and unable to weight bear with a broken ankle. This is totally unacceptable. Could someone please just attend to her broken ankle.  
I am totally disgusted at the treatment from the RAH and if my granddaughters ankle has fused in wrong place and she needs an operation please be assured I will be suing.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Robert123
title: Recent surgery
body:
I was admitted to Causeway Hospital on New Years Eve suffering from gallbladder problems  
The condition was diagnosed as Mirizzi Syndrome . I was admitted to Surgical 2 where I was treated with great care and respect and kept informed at all times as to the progression of my treatment. My consultant surgeon was exceptional in that he got a specialist surgeon to do the procedure, the nursing throughout has been exemplary from the trainer nurses to the Ward Sister.  
Always available always ready to listen and totally professional. As this is my third time in hospital in sixty seven years I can only say the standards are way above that which anyone might expect.  
Thank you surgeons and thank you Surgical 2.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: wade16
title: So friendly and professional
body:
I attended the NIBTS blood donation drive in Lisburn.  
From arrival I noted well organised C19 guidance in place.  
The new booking system for donating blood was wonderful as I was efficiently seen by the admin, nursing assistants and nurse present.  
The whole process from arrival , donation of blood and leaving was under one hour. The gentleman supervising me was friendly, professional and knowledgeable.  
I wish to thank the NIBTS team for making me feel safe and supported for donating blood during the pandemic

author: Concerned99
title: Hospital directions
body:
Just thought this may be worth adding my comments to help others trying to find directions to the ward at Ninewells.  
A relative at short notice received an appt to attend outpatients for review of Cancer treatment.  
She found herself unable to print the appropriate plan to park and find directions, plan was not in PDF or jpeg format so A4 printout unusable.  
I searched under the “ coming to hospital” which had no reference link to directions.  
The various NHS Tayside websites when trawled through do have some very good plans of various parts of the hospital with excellent plans including ward numbers, levels etc.  
Suggestion: please attach links to these super plans in the “coming to hospital” and “directions” sections.

author: Rose100
title: X-ray during lockdown
body:
Attended IRH for planned out patient x-ray appointment, even as a nurse I was apprehensive about coming into a hospital during Covid and lockdown.  
I was in the building and had my x-ray and back out within 5 minutes and was delighted with that.  
Staff are door ensuring hand hygiene and social distancing, staff ushering and directing to appropriate place. X-ray staff polite and professional and a clear one way system. Often we here negatives even though there are a lot of unadvertised positives withing the NHS.  
Even though this was a minor event I felt I should highlight the positive and well organised way it was handled. Many Thanks

title: not able to take your call!!!
body:
My mother was seen in Hertfordshire under the old system run by The Practice. I have found over the last 6 years The Practice to always be at the end of the phone. My mother has been waiting for a appointment which should have been in January and when nothing happened i have been trying to contact the new provider to no avail. You leave messages and they don't get back to you. So far rubbish service in comparison to the last provider.
Haven't had the opportunity to test the service yet

title: Cancelled Appointment
body: Visited my GP on 29.01.2019. Was referred for an urgent appointment to see an ophthalmologist. Received a call from Community Health And Eyecare Ltd three days later and was offered an appointment on 05.02.2019. On the day of the appointment, Community Health And Eyecare Ltd phoned to inform me that my appointment was cancelled. The earliest an ophthalmologist can now see me is 20.02.2019. If this is their take on an urgent appointment request, I dread to think how long one would have to wait for a non-urgent appointment...

title: Absolute Disaster
body: My mother in law who is 93 had very recently been advised that she had wet macular degeneration which needed immediate attention and her details were sent to the CHS  Community Healthcare Services who would forward the submission form on to a division called CHEC / Community Health & Eyecare in Fullwood Preston as per the new arrangements brought in in January. CHEC would then receive the electronic submission form and referral letter who are then responsible for assessing the urgency and arranging an appointment within 2 wks. CHEC are then responsible for contacting the relevant optician should they not receive the relevant referral letter with the submission form as they need both to effect the appointment. After a month of distress and agony my MIL went back to the optician 3 separate times to try to find out why she had not got her urgent appointment. She was then told that CHEK had not bothered to CHEK whether they had the relevant documents and her application for appointment had disappeared off the system.. The optician has now sent us proof that the relevant forms and referral was sent which leads me to the only conclusion that CHEC is not fit for purpose.

author: BabeM
title: My recent admission
body:
I have just gotten home after recently after a short stay after taking ill with a heart-related problem. I wanted to commend the staff involved in my care and on treatment. From the moment I phoned 111 and all the way through my patient journey to the point of my discharge a few days later I was treated brilliantly. The ambulance technicians, A & E staff the AMAU staff were all amazing and so professional. Nothing was too much trouble.  
We really are blessed with our NHS but the staff at Dr Grays are truly wonderful. They did everything to put me at ease whilst ensuring my patient journey was as smooth and comfortable as possible. This is such a testament to the staff and their dedication particularly at these unprecedented times.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Minor eyelid surgery
body: Removal of a bump on my eyelid yesterday was super quick, efficient and pain free. The team were kind and reassuring and the location was very convenient for me. It was also very easy to change my appointment date when I need to.

author: DougLip
title: GP Practice Service
body: I would simply like to express my thanks to all staff working at my local GP centre - Gillbrae Medical Practice, in Dumfries, Scotland, and, in particular, Dr Halliday who has given me time and excellent support during what must be, for all in the Practice, a particularly trying period. My health issue is not Covid-19 related, but has nevertheless been attended to with exemplary professionalism by Dr Halliday and other colleagues.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: Better service than I had previously
body: Hi All. What a great experience.  Polite kind and in and out.  Explained the outcome and answered questions. What more can I ask for

author: Pip2021
title: Wig service at Fern Centre
body: The ladies were very helpful and friendly - brought a lot of wigs to choose from and gave honest helpful opinions and advice. Great Service

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: redsky32
title: Absolute angels on this earth.
body: I had received a positive covid result 6 days before I had to call 111. Through my tears and struggling to breathe the call handler managed to calm me down and got a nurse to speak to me. After I explained my symptoms and what my GP had told me on the phone earlier, the nurse came back to tell me she was calling paramedics to come assess my breathing. Within 15 mins an ambulance was there to take me to hospital where I spent the next 4 days with covid pneumonia. Absolute angels on this earth, thank you to the call handler and nurse from the bottom of my heart!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: DerbyshireLady
title: Fantastic Service - Fern Centre
body: Fantastic service in these difficult times. Lovely friendly staff & experienced helpers! Thank you

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Swappy
title: My biopsy, on 20th January 2021
body: Had an appointment for a biopsy. Was asked at reception to fill in a form, regarding aspects of my health, medications I was on. Went to toilet, as I felt the need to urinate. A kind nurse came and took me round to a curtained cubicle, asked me to undress and to provide a urine sample. After drinking over 2 Litres of water, I was happy to oblige! Same nurse took blood samples and administered intravenous anti-biotics. The surgeon, who was going to carry out the procedure, came around; introduced himself and informed me of what he was going to do. Nice to be kept in the picture.. a staff member came along and took me into the operating theatre. He explained what was going to happen and that he would keep me informed throughout the procedure of what would be happening next.I was introduced to the theatre team and was rewarded with many smiles. All, very reassuring. . the same staff member was there, all the way through and communicated very effectively. Totally painless biopsy and was then wheeled back into my "changing room", had a cup of tea and biscuits, plus another invite to urinate. Managed the tea and pee, left a happy chappie to go home with my wife. GREAT WORK by a top team. Just a couple of observations. Letting me know that I had to provide urine samples beforehand would've been nice. Fro check in to check out was around 2.5 hours. My wife could have gone shopping if she had known this. Otherwise, a "Rolls Royce" procedure, from start to finish. My thanks and congratulations to all the team members; involved in my operation.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Cavi2015
title: Breastfeeding support during lockdown
body: I had a baby a week before the first lockdown in 2020 and intended to breastfeed despite it being my second baby I had never breastfed before. I was given great support in hospital by both midwifes and auxiliary staff and I felt semi confident when I was discharged after a one night stay in the postnatal ward. By the time my baby was 3 days old I was struggling with lots of pain whilst breastfeeding and needed support. When my community Midwife visited me she said my pain was due to damage but I should contact breastfeeding support for a visit. I immediately called the local breastfeeding team and spoke with someone who informed me due to pandemic they were not allowed to visit me in my home and I should speak to my Midwife. I felt so deflated and unsupported. My Midwife had already been and didn't offer great help apart from telling me to call the breastfeeding support team. I felt like no one would come near me to help and I was in agony. I managed to feed my baby for one more day but then stopped as I was so so sore and just didn't know who else to turn to. It really affected me and I believe it contributed to my very poor mental health in the months that followed. If someone had just taken me under their wing and offered to help who knows I might still be breastfeeding now but it hasn't turned out like that. I felt very let down but these services and all due to a pandemic which I felt made them scared and no one knew what was happening and what services were allowed and which were not.

author: DIT DIT
title: Dedication at a difficult time
body: Yet again, NHS wins a Blue Peter Badge !! It never ceases to amaze me that not withstanding all the pressures that hospitals are under, they still manage to maintain that stiff upper lip. Arrived at QMH today for 1550 appointment. Summoned by a smiling nurse at 1548 and escorted to a room attended by 2 smiling consultants. The progression of my treatment was explained to me in detail. On completion, the still smiling nurse issued me with all relevant paperwork and took time to explain the finer details to me. At the end of what must have been yet another trying week for all of them, I can only offer my sincere thanks for their dedication at this difficult time. Well done all.

author: Lizsy43
title: MRI department
body: We attended an appointment for my daughter today and just wanted to feedback what a fantastic experience we had. I was worried about how my daughter would cope with being in the MRI scanner as she is quite young but the staff were fantastic. From booking the appointment to saying goodbye. This team were so welcoming, reassuring and explained everything to her really well. They talked her through the whole process and checked on her throughout the scan. I was especially grateful to Darren the radiographer who was kind, patient and made my daughter feel completely at ease throughout. What an awesome team, thanks for all you do.

author: Juggler Vain
title: COVID-19 Vaccination
body: Very impressed with the organisation of the new Vaccination Centre and the very helpful, considerate and cheerfulness of all he volunteers and medical staff. But I was surprised by how few people turned up for vaccination. I was one of a only a handful at 6.30pm.and was treated immediately on arrival even though I arrived 30 minutes early. If this represents the failure of people with appointments not turning up, I feel stronger measures should be taken to deal with this.

author: Ma2021
title: Unprofessional staff manner
body:
Such a bad experience at St.Thomas Antenatal clinic.  
For 24 weeks pregnant none of the midwifes told me anything helpful for the pregnancy I was google or asking friends.  
I feel that lots of mistakes were made. They said I have few diseases which I don’t have. I was doing blood tests for anaemia nobody called me to tell me the results without me asking. Not responding always to the emails.  
First scan should be emotional moment for the mother, well the staff member was so rude and cold and I couldn’t enjoy the moment unfortunately. Staff members on reception I also felt were super rude, disrespectful with sad faces. The only nice people were the people taking the blood.  
I moved to another hospital as I felt that I couldn’t trust anyone from there after the errors and staff attitude received by this department.  
Hardly not recommend to anyone, or wishing best of luck!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Dilliaf1
title: My husbands cancer
body: All I can say is my husband has had and is in remission from throat cancer, I have nothing but complete admiration for the whole of castle hills nurses doctors, after care team have done for him, not only them but the cleaners cooks receptionists and ground people for all they do ( sorry if I missed anyone) what a wonderful team you all are, you do not only look after the patient but their loved ones too... YOU, TO MY HUSBAND AND I ARE HEROES. Total respect, you should be so proud xxx🥰🥰🥰🥰xxxx

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

author: Tillytrotter
title: My care
body:
What an amazing team of nurses and health care assistants.  
I spent 4 weeks with these people on medical lounge (Surgical) so caring, friendly always got time to chat to you. They are so hard working, dedicated, do long hours and not well enough paid!!  
They've got halos so bright!! I am going to miss all of them 😔  
Xxxxx

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: sigmasj89
title: Disappointed at the care I was given.
body:
I called NHS24 on a Sunday afternoon in December 2020. I had a very severe acute pain in my mid to lower back. I waited 45 minutes for my call to be answered which I did not mind as I understood the pressure the service was under due to the pandemic.  
When my call was answered by a call handler they were pleasant and asked me a series of questions before seeking advice from a Nurse practitioner on duty. Unfortunately that is where the good service ends as I felt the nurse did not appreciate the severity of my case, I am a young healthy women who should not have been in pain like I was. I was told to take over the counter pain relief and call back if anything changed. I was writhing around in pain but was not listened to.  
I myself am a Health professional and felt disappointed at the care I was given. I held out and called my GP Monday and was sent for an urgent scan and it discovered a serious kidney condition which could have been discovered earlier if the Nurse at NHS24 had been a little more understanding. I felt due to the fact I wasn't calling with covid issues I was not a priority and this is not what our NHS stands for. I am now receiving very good timely care from the local urology team and I cannot fault the care I have been given by my GP and local acute hospital.

author: Grexx95
title: Knee replacement
body: I was sent home yesterday and cannot praise the hospital staff enough from the very beginning I was treated with great care  and made to feel at ease. In the operating room I was made to feel very important and cared for. , talking to me with reassurance all the time. Such fantastic and warm people. My  after care was equally fantastic nothing was too much trouble.   Thank goodness for such brilliant people. I feel like I have made new friends. Thankyou doesn't seem enough, but I am truly thankful for all yor care.

author: Belperresident
title: Covid vaccination
body:
Having heard some friends recount their experiences of Covid vaccination centres outside Derbyshire, I was very apprehensive when my turn for vaccination came. Their tales could be summarised as barely organised chaos. They agreed that they were concerned that they were at risk of infection, with large numbers of people milling around, little attempt at social distancing and stewards not really knowing what to do. I really did not want to throw away what was nearly a year of isolation.  
I found out I had no need to worry. I attended the vaccination facility at Babbington Hospital in Belper, and was extremely impressed. An army of stewards were wonderful. Those outside must have been freezing and all must have been exhausted as it was after 5pm, nearly the end of a long hard day. Every one of them was cheerful - and not a forced cheerfulness of 'we've been told to be nice to people', but a genuine warmth. Every one of them interacted with me as I worked my way to the vaccination area. Virtually all of us seemed to be in the 75+ age group like myself, and there was no hint of patronising, sadly so common when encountering people in their position. No 'Come along deary' but lots of 'Hi, how are you doing, are you OK?'.  
There was a chain of people on hand to give information from the car park entrance to the injection area. Passing one of them, there was always another in sight. At no time was I left wondering where to go next.  
This is a mammoth undertaking, organised at relatively short notice, and needing a lot of people to make it work. I just wish I could thank everyone who was there personally. They were brilliant.

readBy.name: Derbyshire Community Health Services NHS Foundation Trust

author: deno
title: Mixed review of my inpatient stay
body:
Vernon ward St James  
From my recent experience I feel this ward was one of the worst for cleanliness and support from staff.  
After spending 2 days in ICU I was brought up to Vernon Ward. On arrival no staff actually came to see how I was, I felt they were too worried about getting the people who were being discharged, discharged.  
I was still sleeping in my bed with blood all over it 2 days in.  
I was told my wound will need dressing and changing by my surgeon, day 2 every staff member I asked had something to say, ill ask the nurse in charge, I don't have any time ill pass this onto the next shift.  
On day 3 I noticed my stoma bag was leaking so asked them to give me something to clean the wound and some dressing. Someone did come and give it to me but didn't offer to clean or change it for me. Considering I just had surgery and a huge cut in my abdomen, was difficult to bend or see what I was doing. Managed to clean it and put a new dressing on it myself. I found the whole experience on this ward very much disappointing and distressing.  
On asking one nurse if I could have alternative pain relief that my Consultant had recommended, the nurse just walked away. the nurse came back and informed me their computer wasn't working...why didn't they just tell me that, then the same nurse just came over and gave me a cup of medication, didn't even tell me what it was until I called them back to ask.  
I just felt staff on this ward just seem too busy for the patients and their patient focused care has somewhat been compromised!  
I understand that on some of these days they may have been short staffed and over run by new admissions but I found that from my experience some of the HCA seemed reluctant to carry out some of the duties.  
However there were the odd few that actually did want to assist and help, which was nice when you came across them. 2 staff members were truly amazing. It was easy to approach the and when asking them questions one of these staff members took the time to talk and explain things, unlike some of the other professionals on the ward. Another staff member also took patient care into consideration, a very old lady opposite me was crying and before I could press my buzzer they noticed and came over to her.  
Also, I had emptied my urine in bowl and took it to the nurses station, one of the nurses who was really busy asked a HSA to take it from me and they refused. The nurse said OK let me get my gloves and ill take it which they did. The nurse was busy writing up notes on the days events and actually the HCA was just walking around.  
I was quite cold one night so I asked a senior staff member if they could get me an extra blanket and maybe turn the heating on. They said they have no control over the heating and its maintenance that do it. So this whole time there was no heating on, on this floor. And I didn't get a blanket! Also this same nurse, woke me up at 6am to ask if I wanted pain relief, when I said yes, I was told I need to eat first! Then why wake me up at 6am?  
I stayed on Grey Ward some years back and the situation was the same. I would have thought it would've changed by now.  
I really wouldn't want any of my relatives to stay on Vernon Ward.  
Credit to some of the staff were all really helpful and supportive.  
Intensive Care Unit, what a difference. The nurse who was looking after me really attended to me and gave me so much support when it was needed, not to say I didn't need as much support when I was moved to the ward.  
They are very attentive to your recovery in ICU and really tried to prepare me as much as they could to go onto the ward .

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Vaccinee
title: Covid vaccination
body: Extremely friendly staff, putting my nerves at ease. Great socially distanced set up and efficiently organised.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: slidebb43
title: Virtual visiting
body: Congratulations to all concerned on the wonderful service offered to families whose loved ones are in hospital during this dreadful pandemic. Our virtual visit is our lifeline and the highlight of our day. Thank you so much for all that you do

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Orla87
title: Well organised
body:
I received the covid vaccine today- a little apprehensive however all the stuff were very welcoming, helpful, professional and gave a lot of insight and reassurance to me regarding the vaccine, procedure and aftercare- the vaccine itself was fine to have- a small pinch and it was complete.  
The entire process was very well organised- that along with the very friendly staff (Eileen in particular) made me very relaxed and confident in having the covid vaccine

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Straighttothepoint
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body: Went to Craigavon Centre. Very happy with arrangements there - very professional. Plenty of car parking spaces outside and plenty of room inside. Will come again!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: oscarnj66
title: covid vaccine appointment
body:
I should like to congratulate Heatherview Medical Centre on its organization of the covid session. I arrived early and because of restricted parking reserved for Blue Badges, I was politely asked to park in the large car park at Sainsbury's. There were two marshals dealing with the traffic and another guiding the patients to either GP appointments or the vaccination queue. Two Poly-tunnels had been set up for protection from the weather and the patients flowed through without too much waiting around. Once my temperature had been taken and I had checked in and sanitised, I was swiftly taken to a treatment room where one person took my details and a second asked me the essential questions and administered the 'jab'. The explanations were clear and not rushed, and I was then escorted to the main waiting area to sit for 5 minutes to ensure all was well.  
I estimate there must have been about 20 staff (both clinical and assistants) circulating in a reasonably confined area, and yet their routine worked without a hitch.  
Please pass on my thanks and congratulations to all at Heatherview for their outstanding efforts to make getting the vaccine and calm and swift experience.

author: Another frustrated
title: Access to vaccinations for a housebound 95 year old
body:
I have now being trying to access a CV19 vaccination to my housebound father who lives north of Newark. He has received 2 letters inviting him to a vaccination centre. After contacting everyone including this service, his Dr, my local MP, the 0115 883 4640 vacs booking line which is unavailable!!. This number also refers me to Notts County Council for further information and they are completely void of knowledge on this subject. Trying to engage with the "engagement" team at Notts Health Trust-these take approx a week to reply to my emails and ,to date, haven't been able to tell me what arrangements are in place for the housebound and how to book a visit  
How do I feel?? Totally frustrated and increasingly in despair at the lack of actual service information and total lack of clarity and response to my question.

author: CobraEcosse
title: Treatment and Care - endoscopy
body:
Endosocpy VHK Waiting area 2  
The care and attention that I received from all staff was fabulous, from the assistance from the ambulance driver to to nurses and medical staff. Everyone was friendly and helpful making me feel safe especially with the current pandemic.  
They put me at ease from the moment I arrived. So thankful for the NHS and the fantastic staff.  
Thank you and stay safe.

author: De Laing
title: Thanks Elgin Ambulance Service
body:
I am writing this on behalf of my 74 year old father who needed the rapid response of the paramedic team after having a seizure in bed at 3.30am a day ago.  
He cannot thank the ambulance and its team enough for their amazing care when they responded to his wife's call for help and he is very grateful for their professional and kind manner.  
We are so lucky to have such a dedicated and supportive service that we wanted to show our appreciation with this feedback.  
They helped calm his wife on their arrival and provided a high standard of care.  
Thank you .

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Screwdriver
title: COVID vaccination
body:
Had the vaccine
So so easy was completed before I realised and never felt the injection
All good
Well done NHS

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: memberzn63
title: Ward 17 Monklands.....Fantastic care
body:
I have recently been admitted to Monklands hospital after taking unwell following a positive covid 19 test. I was admitted to ward 17 where I was given 1st class care and attention from a wonderful group of nurses and doctors throughout my 9 day stay.  
I witnessed 1st hand how dedicated and hard working all your staff are especially under these difficult circumstances. Nothing was ever a bother to any of them and they were always happy to help in any way possible.  
Thank you for the fabulous care I received you are all amazing at what you do and are a credit to NHS Lanarkshire.

author: Hapnn94
title: Cardioversion and ablation
body: I have had an ablation and 2 cardio versions at Eastbourne General over the last few years. Under the care of Dr Furniss and Sister Marie I have had excellent treatment every time. I know when I go in I will be treated with care and consideration and therefore have no anxiety about having treatment. I feel very lucky to live somewhere where I can receive such excellent treatment and care. Well done to all the staff in the Cardiology Dept.

author: nachosmile
title: Birth of Baby Girl
body: I want to thank everyone who helped with the birth of my baby daughter at the start of January. The midwives and support staff in Maternity Triage, the team on Ward 7, the support staff, midwives, paediatrics team, domestics, house keepers in ward 8, everyone were just wonderful and I can’t thank them enough. After a speedy delivery and bit of a traumatic time, the entire team were amazing. They supported me after a trip to theatre, They gave great emotional support when I was having a bit of a tough time after my labour and my wee one having to stay in for 4 days. I really appreciated the debrief given by the doctor from ward 7 the following day to explain what had happened during my labour as it was all a bit of a blur at the time! I really must thank all of the support given by staff with breastfeeding as well. I feel their support has really helped me to succeed with feeding at home. I can appreciate how stressful things can be at the moment with COVID-19 but all the staff were very professional, caring and supportive for me and my family during this whole experience. Thank you again!

author: magpiezf67
title: Stay in hospital before elective section
body: After arrival was shown where I would be staying before having my baby by elective section. All staff could not have been any friendlier and treated with dignity and respectful by all staff. Made my stay very pleasurable. Was very well looked after by staff that cared and showed genuine compassion towards myself. Could not have asked for anything better. A big thank you to all staff on ward 31 both a and b and of course to the consultants, midwives and all others involved in the labour suite. I am truly grateful for such competent staff during the delivery of my baby girl. Once again thank you very much.

author: the big yin
title: Endoscopy procedure
body:
I had colonoscopy carried out at endoscopy day unit run by C/N Katie.  
From reception to pre/op and post/op care , very good communication and caring staff very professional  
My procedure went very well staff kept me relaxed and talked about what was happening all the time  
Special Thanks to DR Wilson and the canny Geordie nurse who put me at ease during my colonoscopy also special thanks S/N Dryburgh, S/N Parker during this investigation  
Also many thanks to Jill and Claire for post op care this was really appreciated ,Very professional run clinic by C/N Katie.  
Well done to all staff Care process was Faultless keep up the good work.

author: Jac63
title: Covid vaccine for my son
body:
I'm extremely worried that my son's classification has been changed from Clinically Extremely Vulnerable to normal, regarding administration of the Covid Vaccine, despite no change in his condition.  
We live in Belfast. In March 2020 he was notified to shield. He did so for four months.  
His condition is still clearly identified by The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation for priority vaccination however my GP reports The Department of Health have failed to prioritise him.  
I fear there has been an error. I worry about possible fatal detriment.  
I have raised my concerns in writing with my GP practice. They have failed to respond.  
I have made numerous attempts to speak with the Vaccination Team in DoH. They do not respond.  
I'm seeking help to have my sons classification decision reviewed as a matter of urgency. I do not know how to progress this considering my lack of success to date.  
CAN ANYONE PLEASE HELP ME TO HELP MY ONLY SON?.

author: FPL52
title: I owe them a debt of gratitude.
body:
I had a cardiac arrest last March just at the start of the first lockdown and was taken to the Cardiology Dept at Hairmyres. I had a ‘balloon pump’ fitted by an outstanding team and after some critical days in the care of the utterly wonderful staff in CCU (especially nurse Catriona and her colleagues), I was moved to Ward 9. Because of complications, I spent a further 5 weeks there before having an ICD fitted by Dr Glen and Consultant Dr O’Rourke. In Ward 9, notwithstanding the height of the pandemic, the exemplary nature of care and professionalism continued from Consultant Dr MacDougall and Dr Pitcaithly to nurses (especially Lucy and Sam) and support staff.  
I recently returned to the Cardiology Dept for the first time since my discharge for a routine scan. Somewhat to my surprise, I found myself very moved by this visit. Once again the professionalism and personal care was outstanding (thank you Joanne!). It would have been wonderful to meet again (and thank) some of the staff face to face but that was not possible. I owe them a debt of gratitude I will never be able to repay. At the time I did try to write a personal note of thanks to everyone who contributed to my treatment and recovery, inevitably I will have missed someone out. I hope this note goes some way to help make up for that.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: 123js49
title: Gynaecology procedure
body:
I received an appointment to attend within 2 days of a scan result felt a bit nervous about the outcome. Attended the gynaecology ward to be told I was having a procedure done when I hadn’t spoken to any doctor about the result or what was to happen.  
On arrival I felt nervous as I am already receiving cancer treatment. The staff nurse met me and was very kind showed me to a side room and reassured me the doctor would explain everything . I waited a very short time when the consultant then the registrar spoke to me and explained everything about the procedure and why it was necessary.  
On being shown to the room for procedure three nurses were very welcoming and put me at ease. The nurses took there time with me and explained every stage then the registrar explained every step he was taking and told me to say if I was sore or needed him to stop at any point. I found the whole experience extremely efficient the staff very calm and kind with every step.  
I became tearful after the procedure just from relief of the positive outcome but one nurse in particular was very kind to me but the registrar also asked if I was alright. I have had many appointments and procedures done and this was one of the best I’ve experienced. I’m sure I was the last patient of the day as late in the day but did not feel rushed or feel as though the staff wanted to get home which I’m sure they would be.  
Thank you so much to all the staff involved for making it a very positive experience.  
[Very happy with 'Doctor']  
  
[Very happy with 'Nurses']  
  
[Very happy with 'Introductions']

author: CAH patient
title: Great care
body:
I recently visited the early pregnancy unit and subsequently had to have surgery. The care, advice and support I received from the team was fantastic. Dr Finnegan was excellent and kept me well informed on my options. She made sure I was ok until I got a bed in 2West while I was waiting to hear when my surgery would be. The nursing team were so lovely. Julie-Anne and Rachel were so attentive and made me feel well cared for. Nothing was any trouble. They were so warm and caring.  
As I wasn’t to get surgery until the following morning and hadn’t eaten all day they made me tea and toast. I was visited by the register Lyndsey and again she was great and explained things really clearly. I couldn’t have asked for better care. The next morning I was told I was going for surgery and Mark the anaesthetist went through the procedure and reassured me about the surgery. I was nervous about surgery and so when was taken to theatre Mark and the team were very reassuring. I felt in safe hands.  
I woke up in recovery where again I was looked after by a fantastic team of nurses. I was weak with hunger so they made me tea and toast. They checked on me regularly and again the care I received was fantastic. I was then moved to 4North and Holly looked after me that evening. She was great, so personable and friendly. At a time that was very traumatic and scary I cannot praise the teams at CAH enough. I always felt safe, informed and the compassionate care I received was excellent! A big thank you to everyone. I know there are names I have forgotten.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rho
title: Coronavirus vaccinations
body: Brought 90yr old mum to Motherwell Health Centre for vaccination - excellent organisation. Great staff (Dr mcAlpine surgery)

author: aurigagp58
title: Love the NHS
body:
Sunday Jan 2021  
I have just had my Covid vaccination this morning at Shirley House and I just wanted to pass on my sincere thanks and gratitude to all the staff who were working today, Sunday, with little regard for their own safety, to keep the rest of us safe. In particular the nurse Helen, who dealt with me so professionally and courteously. Many, many thanks indeed.

author: Grudge55
title: Roll out of Covid- 19 Vaccine
body: Today I received my first Covid 19 vaccination in Northern Ireland - a well organised and well executed operation   - Thank you NHS 👍👍

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Cpblock
title: Receiving COVID 19 vaccination
body: Everything was very easy, good access, facilities, nurses and staff all very helpful.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: eimearlegal
title: Seamless process
body:
Everything seamless
Caring and efficient
Very thorough process
Eileen was very clear and made me feel at ease
injection painless and no after effects thus far

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: R58
title: Unpleasant appointment
body:
I have been a sufferer of a mesh injury. This story is not really mesh related, but could be .. went to hospital yesterday for my appointment to get cataracts removed .. I can’t say it was the most pleasant appointment .. Staff and Consultant very abrupt .. it seemed to me that they are skeptical about mesh-injured people .. Put me right off having it done .. I have a very dense cataract in my right eye .. The consultant asked me over and over if I’ve ever had trauma to right eye .. had a poor attitude, sighing and generally making me feel stupid .. All because I mentioned that I know mesh injured ladies can have problems with eyes ..  
Feel so upset 😥.

author: SmurfDoctor01
title: Support has truly changed my life
body:
I was addicted to cocaine over the course of 4/5 years, I truly thought that there wasnt hope left and that I wouldn't manage to get sober  
Then I joined CGL and was assigned Adrian as my key worker, who helped me turn everything around- he moves mountains for every service user and he became the father figure that I didnt have. Without him I honestly do not believe I would have come so far in my sobriety. He was my number one supporter, my best friend and the one that would hold me accountable whilst at the same time giving me so much encoragement  
He truly has changed my life

author: caringdc85
title: COVID vaccine
body: Feeling great after my vaccination .. very slick operation with lovely staff

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: FC2021
title: Fern Centre
body: Very happy with the ladies help, they put me at ease

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: June13
title: You are all heroes to us.
body:
In October of last year my husband Andy collapsed at his work in Ayrshire central kitchen and passed away in Crosshouse ED resus at 7.21am.  
My family and I would like to thank all the staff that he worked with in the kitchen for what they did that morning and the trauma they went through I can’t imagine how hard that was for all of them . To the crash team at woodlands view , the nurse practitioner who called me to keep me Informed of Andy being transferred to Crosshouse . To the paramedics , all the staff in Crosshouse resus that morning Nursing staff and Doctors who tried to save him.  
We appreciate all you did to try and bring him back to life but it wasn’t to be.  
You are all hero’s to us and can’t thank you enough for your kindness , care and attention on such a harrowing and traumatic experience for my family.  
Please can you make sure all staff involved that day know how much we truly appreciate their care and efforts to save our much loved Andy.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Scottygran
title: Care in Coronary Care Unit Scarborough Hospital
body:
I was admitted to CCU after being assessed in A&E. I was put on a monitor and then assessed for the fitting of a pacemaker. At all times the staff were compassionate, kind, sensitive to my anxieties, supportive, reassuring and considerate of my needs. I would like to recommend Albert for a special mention as his smiley face and sense of humour were such a morale booster. He was such a shining light!! Other members of staff on this ward were so caring from the Lead Sister, Vicky, to the lovely tea lady, Shirley. Every area was well serviced and the whole ward seemed to jog along like a well oiled machine. Nothing was too much trouble for any one of the staff and, obviously Vicky led from the front and was well supported by Deputy Sisters Gemma and Amanda. Ethel is another member of staff worthy of a mention, she is such a warm hearted, caring, lovely lady. It is very hard to single out any other members of staff as name labels were covered with the plastic aprons!! I would like to say that the care and courteous manner with which I was treated by everyone could not have been bettered had I paid!  
There is, of course, an exception to this rule. Sad to say that the technician who carried out an ultra sound, was not in the least courteous. I couldn't tell you what they were called as they never introduced themselves, just turned up at the ward door (I was in a single room), with a machine and proceeded to move the bed, asking if I could help (?) and the locker, so that they could get the machine into the room. I eventually had to ask them what they were doing, after they removed my pyjama top and covered part of my body with a sheet. I had a cannular in my left arm and was asked to hold my left breast out of the way of this instrument. I could only do this for a short period of time as the needle, in the cannular, was becoming really painful. I tried to use my right arm, but was told, quite sharply, that that was no good. This is the only time, during my stay in CCU that I just felt like a piece of meat on a butcher's slab. There has to be an exception to the rule and this person was it for me. Good manner cost nothing and the least this person could have done was to introduce themselves and tell me what they were going to do. Not rocket science.  
Everyone else, First Class Treatment, First Class Caring and First Class Professionalism.  
I would like to commend all the Cardiologist team. They kept me in the picture about what was going to happen and I had every confidence in them. The surgeon who did the procedure, Mr. Ahkmed, (apologies for the spelling) was just fantastic and confidence came out of every pore. He had a great sense of humour, which was complimented by the staff, in the department, where the procedure was carried out. At no time whatsoever did I feel that I was not in the most professional of hands. Thank you all,

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Danmz93
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Relapse Prevention Support
body:
Just wanted to say that I am discharged from One Recovery. I would like to thank you and everyone in the Relapse Prevention group for all the help and support you gave me. All of you made me stronger and ready for a new chapter in my life, which I am very excited about. I started One Recovery exactly one year ago. I went through hills and mountains to be in the place I am right now. In the first few months there were lots of tears, lots of anger, lots of emotions, which were changing just like a tornado changing directions unexpectedly. I had a relapse and lapse, which later on I realised that actually it made me even stronger. I felt like a toddler who is trying to learn how to walk again. Every fall I had I was getting up and walking even more comfortable. But I had so many hands picking me up everytime I fell. Those hands made me stronger and steadier on my feet. You were those hands. I have to say, iIt was a rollercoaster ride. Then came the calm after the storm, realizing how much I archived by staying sober. How much I gained in the eyes of my child and my husband's. There I was, in front of them, the way I should be at all times. Just pure me, not hiding behind the glass of wine, not drowning in tears every morning, not being hungover and feeling ashamed and disgusted with myself. The day came when I was finally happy.  
Everyone in One Recovery was part of my journey and I will be always extremely grateful for everything. I will always keep you all in my prayers, to give you strength to achieve anything you desire.  
Stay strong!!!!! You can do it. If I did it you can do it as well. ☺  
I will miss you all very much.  
Stay strong.

author: Danmz93
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Family Service
body: I just wanted to say a huge thankyou to your and the whole One Recovery Team for setting up the new Peer Support Group. I cannot tell you how fantastic it already is. We have set up a WhatsApp group and have already lent each other so much support. It is a sign of these COVID times that such a group is needed. We would naturally have left normal, face to face group therapy and gravitated to each other to form support and friendship bubbles. This lack of this physical contact and natural progression must have put a massive pressure and on your already overburdened services. I do hope it alleviates a little of your workloads, as I feel sure we will become the rocks to each other that we have relied solely upon you for over the last many months. To find the funding and time for this extra service is more than appreciated and I thank you once again for the absolutely outstanding service you personally offer.

author: Two struggling parents
title: My alcoholic son
body: We were struggling to help our then 22/23 year old alcoholic son.. life was just existing on our part.. we would go from day to day trying to keep someone stay sober who didn’t want to be... we were honestly exhausted.. I was put in touch with one of the parent support workers.. Straight away from the first meeting I felt relaxed to talk over such hard things which had been happening... I had no one else other than family to confide in... I felt guilty.. My parent support worker was so understanding and listened and helped me so much, explaining that it was not my fault this was happening, that was invaluable to hear.. Over time we have been given such great help and advice for us and our son... we have all had separate sessions as well... The support is for us all.. The counsellor has been there for us whenever we needed help and still are... I honestly cannot rate this service higher.. I would recommend them to anyone who is going through a really tough time..

author: Emmrd63
title: IMCA at Court
body:
I write further to today’s hearing to express our gratitude.  
I wish to pass on my thanks to Bethan for the way in which she presented herself in court and for being able to review the paperwork which was being sent very late in the day. She was excellent, especially considering that she doesn’t usually deal with these types of matters.

author: Emmrd63
title: Litigation Friend
body: Thank you very much for agreeing to act as Litigation Friend today Bethan– much appreciated. I thought you were really good – your explanation of your position was succinct and pertinent!

author: waltznr47
title: Covid vaccination
body: Everything went very smoothly. So well organised at the vaccination centre. No queues and everything explained by the trained staff. Injection wasn’t sore, hardly felt it going in. No reaction after. Arm slightly sore the next day but no other side effects. Can’t wait to get my second one!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Bambi_mae
title: Maternity services
body: I ended up in for 8 nights in AAH when my waters broke 4 weeks early. Our baby arrived after 4 nights and the staff on the ward couldn't have been better. I had been due to give birth elsewhere and knew the team there so was anxious about the move but the midwives, assistants and Doctors couldn't have been better. On the ward Joanne, Jessica and Shelley couldn't have done more for me, along with the rest of the girls. They helped keep my morale up as I got tired of waiting around both before and after the birth. They also helped ensure our breastfeeding journey got off to the best start it possibly could have, spending time with us that I really needed. They managed to make me laugh when I was feeling at my lowest and were a listening ear when I was struggling on the notorious day 3! Shelley was training as a student at the time but I know she is going to be one of the most amazing midwives, that I would love to have by my side again. On the labour ward, particularly Esther and Dr Donald along with the rest of the team made my birthing experience one that I will never forget for all the right reasons. They talked me through every step, including me in all decisions and helping me to feel comfortable and safe when things got a little difficult. As I have had previous health problems of my own, I was aware my birth plan was a hope rather than set in stone, but they still made attempts to respect this whilst keeping me and our son safe. Esther in particular, was a ray of sunshine who both me, my husband and my mum, told everyone about after the birth. However, we honestly couldn't speak more highly of them all as a team. They are a credit to their professions and I don't think any of them realise how amazing they truly are.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jo1jd99
title: Disgusting food
body: The food is so bad it doesn’t matter how hungry I was, I just couldn’t eat it.

readBy.name: East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust

author: Alalf
title: My Covid Jab
body: I booked my vaccination for 13-20 in the afternoon. My wife's appointment was two hours later. The process was stress free with the staff doing a wonderful job during this difficult time. When I had my injection I asked if there was any chance my wife could have her jab now to save us having to wait for a lengthy period in the car park. The member of staff who injected me checked with the administration staff and agreed to my request. I can only say a big THANK YOU. Well-done.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Thomas.
title: Video call
body:
Availed of the video calling service provided by the hospital. At the time the call was to happen, my father was moved between wards but thankfully the video team successfully tracked him down. The call was good for everyone involved as we have only had normal phone calls over the last week.
Very good service under what must be a very demanding time for everyone in the hospital. Our sincere thanks to everyone for making this happen. It really is a valuable service enabling loved ones to actually see each other.
Thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: GreenHay
title: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
body: Definitely the right choice for me! And was definitely worth waiting for! I enjoyed the couple of months with my therapist, it really helped me and I have noticed a big difference! I was sad when coming to the end but I would definitely do it again if I ever needed to! My therapist was so lovely and relatable! She understood everything I spoke about and went through every single thing with me! Obviously this isnt a miracle cure but it was great to have someone to talk too and someone who listened and knew what u was talking about, it seemed like she really cared about what I was saying and im super grateful for that as that is important in therapy!

author: volanskb89
title: Excellent service
body:
I am very impressed and very grateful by the excellent service and the quiet professional and caring attitude of the staff
I lived these past four years in Congo running an Ebola programme and we prayed every day for a vaccine. So to be offered this Covid vaccine is an absolute blessing

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Teribus
title: Carpal Tunnel Operation
body: I had my op last week and wanted to say how impressed I was with everyone involved in my hospital visit, each one of them was very polite and caring, even a lovely young man who got me into the Ward when I didn't know how to operate the entry system! The operation itself was, for me, a daunting thought as I am admittedly a coward in such circumstances, but every member of the team tried to put me at ease to help me through. Although I was dreading it, they were 100% supportive and the mood in the theatre was relaxed and very positive. I love Dr Williamson, she is so personable and I felt very safe in her hands (excuse the pun! ). I am very grateful to each and every person involved in my small op, you all made me feel as comfortable as possible. We are so very lucky to have you, you are all heroes, all the time, but even more so in the current circumstances. I am in awe of you.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Laurasp
title: Midwifery Led Unit
body: I would like to pass in my sincere thanks and gratitude to the staff in both the assessment unit (student midwife Paula), and the Midwifery Led Unit (Sister Louis and team) for the very swift delivery of our daughter shortly after our arrival to the hospital on the 26th January. You all jumped into action and your care and attention was second to none and a shining example of what Midwifery led care should be, completely person centred and supportive. We were back home within a few hours. Thank you for making our Journey such a positive experience.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: plusjr67
title: Care from Grace centre
body:
After being referred by my GP, I had an appointment at the GRACE centre to check something more closely. I just wanted to thank the staff who carried out my appointment and examination for taking the time to explain things to me clearly. I felt that they really took the time to listen and explain things to me, which I really valued. They made me feel comfortable and I just wanted to pass on my thanks for the way the appointment was handled and just the general way I was treated and cared for.  
I was a little nervous about going, and nearly cancelled when the initial symptoms I'd had went away just before the appointment. However, family convinced me it was still important to get checked.  
The doctor that completed the examination was brilliant, and I just wanted to say thank you for everything. Working in a service based industry myself, I know the importance of getting feedback, hence just wanting to write and say thank you again.

author: sambagd49
title: Feeling unwell
body:
I had been feeling unwell for a long time with an upset stomach. I was feeling exhausted all the time. What ever I ate or drink just went straight through me, since the end of November. I had a colonoscopy done which showed nothing serious.  
I was still feeling exhausted and my stomach is still playing up. I went to my GP, they took blood and done ECG. Which showed my heart was out of rhythm.  
On Tuesday evening, a Dr James phoned me to tell me that Winchester lab had phoned him to tell him that my magnesium levels was very low, I had to go straight into hospital. I was put on a magnesium infusion. Which helped a lot. That was why my heart wasn't right.  
I really want to thank Winchester hospital lab, Dr James and everyone on McGill ward who looked after me.

author: T4BTY
title: Coronavirus Vaccine
body:
I received my first dose of COVID-19 vaccine this morning in Craigavon, and I must congratulate all concerned in the process. From booking the two appointments on line to actually receiving the jab the whole process was totally seamless. Well done to all concerned.  
Thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Scottygran
title: Hospital Catering
body: I just want to say that the food in Scarborough Hospital was superb.   On one occasion it could have been a bit hotter, but the variety on the menu was excellent and one would have to be really picky not to be able to find something to their liking.   The soups were particularly good and the meal portions were generous.   I have nothing but praise for the kitchen staff who provide such great food, for so many people.   We  done and thankyou all.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Fred2021
title: Great experience at Fern Centre
body: I really enjoyed the wig fitting appointment - the two ladies were very helpful and gave useful opinions and advice. It was a great experience - to see myself with hair again! Thank you!

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Maggieflood
title: Brilliant
body: Im 52 years old I was a shocked and surprised to find out that they were going to amputate my leg in 3 days and because of this covid I was not allowed my family around me, but on ward 12 there is a nurse Lesley who works nightshift who couldn't have been better to settle me down and explained a lot to me. Dont get me wrong, all the nurses and students are great but Lesley in particular was very knowledgeable, such a lovely woman but I know I get my op tomorrow so hopefully she knows how important she is in ward 12. brillant.

author: Lizc49
title: Covid vaccine at South Lakes
body: Extremely well organised smooth procedure.   Staff very helpful, polite and professional.     Made me feel safe and at ease.   Also received lots of relevant information and answers to all my queries.     Thank you to all the staff involved I appreciate getting my first vaccine today and a booking for the 2nd.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Marymo
title: Older people's team
body: My stepmother had a high number of risks due to memory deterioration.   Big thanks to Nurse Caroline Inches and Dr Sharma in securing a diagnosis of mixed dementia and for ensuring a wide range of support and treatment mechanisms were in place during this lockdown period.

author: 2timesdone
title: Treatment by nurses
body:
I was referred by my doctor to Ninewells Surgery admissions.  
I was in agony, my clothes touching my skin was painful.  
I was seated in a waiting area with a couple of other patients. A nurse came in and spoke to one of the patients, then came back moments later with a jug of water and a cup. I just thought that meant we were only allowed water after we had had certain tests taken.  
Around an hour after I arrived a doctor assessed me and took some blood, It was painless . The doctor was very professional, and very patient as I explained my pain and recent lack of sleep. I returned to the waiting area and was told that somebody would check on me intermittently. Over the next 2 hours, a few nurses came and went; checking on other patients in the waiting area.  
I had been trying to cope with the pain because I knew it was only a matter of time until it would get sorted, but I was really struggling, so I went to find a nurse. There were about 5 nurses in the ward next to the waiting area, I said excuse me a few times until one of them met my eyes. I asked if I could please have some painkillers. The nurse told me to go and sit down and someone will bring me something. So I returned to the waiting area, shivering with pain and at this point I had not had anything to drink for about 4 hours.  
40 minutes later, I returned to the nurses and begged them for some pain relief explaining that I had made the same request 40 minutes prior. I was told to be patient because they were very busy. Two minutes later a nurse appeared with two co-codamol, a jug of water and a cup. This lead me to believe that they had ignored or forgotten my first request. I took the medication. Sometime in the next hour, as the pain eased, I noticed a whiteboard on the wall opposite me which read amongst other things "please help yourself to water until you have been fully assessed". And I realised that there was no reason for me or anyone else to be sitting dehydrated. There should have been water available at minimum, because if it takes over 40 minutes to administer painkillers, how long it would have taken had I requested a drink?  
The specialist who ended up treating me and the nurse who aided were both fantastic and very sympathetic about the pain I was in as soon as they saw the affected area. They both apologised for how long I had been waiting.  
I feel that some of the nurses on the ward that I encountered misread my pain as rudeness. I begged for help and felt that I was treated like a pest and told to be "patient". I am sure there are plenty of conscientious nurses working at Ninewells. I just felt it was important to give fully honest feedback.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: woodpigeonmg36
title: Really really well done
body: I had my Covid 19 Vaccination today and I have to say it was excellent. It was at the leisure centre in Craigavon, it was very well organised, very efficient, everyone was lovely. Really really well done, just perfect.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: leost76
title: The whole thing went extremely well
body:
I had a small procedure this morning and I wanted to say well done. Everything was excellent, so here I am to record my pleasure with how it all went.  
It was at the Stirling Community Hospital, Dermatology department. David was the advanced nurse practitioner who did the operation, and the assistant was stacy - the whole thing went extremely well, they were both so helpful.  
Ten out of ten.

author: octansjs57
title: anterial resection for sigmoid tumour
body:
I called my doctor after finding blood in my stool. Fast-tracked a bowel screening test and six days later I was in hospital for a colonoscopy which showed I had a tumour. After an appointment with my consultant surgeon, who explained everything to me and advised that the CT scan showed it hadn't spread I had an appointment with the pre-assessment nurse, Nicola, who was fantastic and took me through everything that was going to happen and what to expect.  
I have to say, it was six weeks between talking to my GP and undergoing surgery to remove the tumour (I was very impressed with the speed at which things happened, especially during this pandemic). I am at home now and my time in hospital with the surgeon, registrar, the anaestheologist team was very well managed and very thoughtful to my needs and my nerves. When I was in the HDU Staff Nurse Kelly and Student Nurse Ana were a godsend, I thank them all very much.

author: Scottygran
title: Quality Care at Scarborough Hospital
body:
I was told to go to A& E by the 111service as I had been experiencing breathlessness, palpitations and dizziness for some considerable time and the medication, which I had been prescribed, didn't appear to have made any difference. After preliminary checks I was taken to a bay in A& E. I was admitted into the care of Carla, an HCA in A& E. Her professional, sympathetic and caring attitude was all too evident in the way in which she put me at ease, while going about her tasks with calm reassurance and in a very kind and considerate manner.  
She inserted a cannular into my arm and when this was removed some 5 days later, there was only the smallest pinprick to show there had been anything there at all. I was also fed and watered regularly! ! Cups of tea were brought without my being made to feel that it was any trouble at all.  
Patient care, second to none. Carla started her shift at 4pm, just as I was being admitted and finished her shift, just as I was taken to a ward. Eight hours of personal care! I would also like to acknowledge another member of staff for a special mention.  
Bethany was also on duty for some of the time I was in A& E. Another warm, sensitive and considerate member of this team. I cannot thank either of them enough for everything they did for me, between them. Nothing was too much trouble and I would like them to get some sort of acknowledgment of my appreciation of all their warm hearted, understanding and helpful treatment I received from them.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Appreciative citizen
title: Covid vaccination
body:
Its been overwhelming watching media coverage of the impact on health care professionals of the strain the NHS has been under for so long, caring for Covid patients. Having just had my first vaccination in Lenton, Nottingham, I have cause to thank them for the service I personally received there.  
After months of staying at home, queuing outside with others suddenly felt as though the whole world was made up exclusively of 70+ year olds - but what an amazing feat of organisation! And all without losing a personal touch from everyone I interacted with - volunteer stewards outside and inside, volunteer 'clerks' and health care professionals alike.  
Credit to Kate for vaccine procurement - but all hail (again... still...) our precious NHS. If only they had been in charge of the whole management of this crisis, nationally and locally, instead of this current government. This is my personal thank you to all those working at the Lenton Covid vaccination centre for exemplifying the best of us.

author: Baron1
title: Covid-19 Vaccine
body: I attended the hospital yesterday for my first Vaccine. I just wanted to say thank you and how much I appreciated the way it was all organised. From car parking to observation at the end of the process, it was so very well done. All the staff were attentive and kind, I realise many of them had given up their time for our benefit. A big thank you to everyone involved.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: achach
title: 2 things could have been better
body:
I have done the covid-19 vaccination and there are couple of things that could be made better.  
It was raining a bit and the small queue had to wait outside unsheltered from rain, when in the waiting room I think there was unnecessary moving of people from seat to seat as people went for the vaccine, in the vaccination area there is good ventilation, but on this day it meant it was quite cold - it would be good to provide small heaters so the staff is not exposed to cold.  
The staff was super nice!

author: caringbd65
title: Caring staff in tough times
body:
Last week I was in Neely ward for 5 days admitted from A and E as a potential surgery patient. What struck me was how hard the staff were working in a busy full ward day and night. The effects of under resourcing and working through a pandemic was obvious and I am sure staff are exhausted. I appreciated the care and concern shown by those nurses who clearly 'knew the ropes'. Being offered human connection, conversation and concern when in a lot of pain, means so much particularly when visitors are not permitted. Thanks Hannah and Clare and a special shout out to Mary who went out of her way to find me gluten free toast!  
My experience was not all reassuring, with many staff new to the ward or appearing inexperienced requiring supervision, maybe due to staffing shortages? In 5 days, 7 different surgeons spoke briefly to me and while I understand the enormous pressures they are under, continuity and taking time to explain would have really helped to give clarity and reduce anxiety.  
Thank you to the staff who keep on going, when patients return home still you go on.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: worthye
title: Darlington Memorial Hospital A&E
body:
I had 3 hrs in A&E with chest pain on my right side after slipping badly on ice, the Receptionist at the door took me into the main area were I was told to sit and wait, I was seen to straight away, the reason I am writing this is because our NHS always seems to be getting bad reports, Well I am telling everyone this Hospital and staff are excellent I was born in 1947 virtually when the NHS began and for 73 years it as looked after me, when I was on long distance I had a accident in Southampton and was taken straight into hospital no ifs or buts anyone wanting this service to go private must be mad, this service is essential for the working people of this country who have already contributed to it.  
All the best to D M Hospital and the wonderful Staff, thank you.
